Key institutional actors—most notably Brazil as host—are on public record as wanting to consolidate, not grow further, citing consensus difficulties and rule-making lag. 'Institutional problems' and lack of joint communiqués further underline the bloc's stretched ability to integrate more new members. None of the most recently discussed potential candidates (Kazakhstan, Turkey, Malaysia, Vietnam, Senegal) have formal status upgrades under discussion; Kazakhstan has just publicly ruled out accession, and there is no evidence of a surprise consensus being assembled versus clear statements to the contrary. While a surprise invitation is not impossible (especially given summit choreography and headline incentives), it would require a last-minute diplomatic shift that has no public signs in the current enviroment. Thus, the probability is quite low, but given the nonzero probability of a strategic play or gesture and the visibility of partners vying for status, it cannot be set at absolute zero.

However, the weight of evidence, bloc politics, and timing all point toward no new invitations, with perhaps some symbolic upgrades to partner or observer status as a consolation but not full membership. Thus, I set the probability close to—but not at—zero.

The base rate (one new member per summit during the active expansion phase) now appears exhausted and the group is entering a pause. As a result, while a Yes outcome remains possible (especially as a symbolic exception or due to a sudden realignment), the best estimate is that an invitation is unlikely barring a major surprise.

question_details.title: Will a new country be invited to BRICS at the 17th BRICS Summit?
question_details.description:
[BRICS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BRICS) is an intergovernmental organization originally founded by Brazil, Russia, India, and China, which held their first formal summit in 2009. South Africa was invited to join in 2010, completing the original five-member grouping. BRICS serves as a forum for cooperation among major emerging economies, with a focus on economic development, political coordination, and reform of international institutions.

At the [15th BRICS Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15th_BRICS_summit) in August 2023, the group announced a major expansion. Full membership invitations were extended to Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. Argentina later declined the invitation, while Saudi Arabia has not formally accepted. Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, and the UAE officially joined on January 1, 2024. 

At the [16th BRICS Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/16th_BRICS_summit) in October 2024, held in Kazan, Russia, BRICS formally introduced a new partner country framework. Thirteen countries were invited as partners at the 16th Summit: Algeria, Belarus, Bolivia, Cuba, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Nigeria, Turkey, Thailand, Uganda, Uzbekistan, and Vietnam. Algeria, Turkey, and Vietnam have not yet confirmed participation. Indonesia later joined as a full member on January 6, 2025.

The 17th BRICS Summit is scheduled to take place on July 6–7, 2025, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Many countries have formally expressed interest in joining BRICS, but new members can only be admitted with unanimous agreement from existing members. While expansion remains a stated goal of the bloc, no new invitations have been confirmed.
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if at least one previously not invited country is invited to join BRICS as a full member during or before the 17th BRICS summit.

This question will only resolve based upon an invitation for full membership, not partner status or any other status in the organisation.
question_details.fine_print:
* An invitation of a partner country to become a full member will resolve this question as **Yes**.
* Reinvitation of Saudi Arabia or Argentina will not be sufficient to resolve this question as **Yes**. 
* Whether or not a country accepts its invitation will have no impact on this question.
* If the 17th BRICS summit is delayed, that will not impact this question unless the delay is to after August 31, 2025, in which case this question will be annulled.
* The specific cutoff for resolution will be 00:00 following the final day of the summit. For example, if the summit is held as expected on July 6-7, the cutoff will be July 8, 00:00. This question will use the timezone of the summit's location, if the summit has no physical location, it will use UTC.
* For the purposes of this question, "country" is defined as a UN member state.

**Brazil to Host Next BRICS Summit in July**
Brazil announced on Saturday that the next BRICS summit will be held in Rio de Janeiro on July 6 and 7. Brazil will chair the group of emerging economies in 2025, focusing on promoting global governance reform and cooperation among Southern Hemisphere countries, according to a statement from the federal government. BRICS was established in 2009 by Brazil, Russia, India, and China, with South Africa joining in 2010. The group expanded last year with the addition of Iran, Egypt, Ethiopia, and the UAE. Saudi Arabia has been invited to join, and Turkey, Azerbaijan, and Malaysia have submitted formal membership requests, with several other countries expressing interest. The group recently welcomed Indonesia as its 11th member and Nigeria as a 'partner country', a classification introduced at the 2024 summit in Kazan. Brazil said that partner countries are also invited to participate in the summit and may attend other meetings if there is consensus among members. Brazilian Foreign Minister Mauro Vieira said, 'We will take decisive actions for development, cooperation, and improving the lives of all citizens in these countries.' US President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened to impose a 100% tariff on BRICS countries if they take steps to undermine the US dollar. BRICS leaders have pledged to create an independent payment system independent of the dollar.

**Palestine Awaits BRICS Observer Status**
The Palestinian Liberation Organization's (OLP) Executive Committee member and Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine Secretary General, Ahmad Majdalani, stated to Sputnik that Palestine is expecting to join the BRICS group as an observer. 'The BRICS is important for Palestine. We have already requested to join as an observer. We don't know when, but we are waiting for it to be approved,' Majdalani mentioned during the XIV Valdái International Club of Debates Conference on the Middle East. Majdalani also highlighted that the presence of countries like Russia and China in the BRICS allows for the counterbalance of the economic power of the United States and the West, and enables the realization of fundamental tasks for the group. 'The BRICS is creating a new system of international relations based on multipolarity. We see this alliance as a kind of counterweight to the economic power of the United States and the West,' he added. In October 2024, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas stated that his country was willing to join the BRICS in any status, whether as a full member, associate, or observer. The BRICS group, initially composed of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, has expanded its membership this year. In January 2024, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, Ethiopia, and Iran joined, and in January 2025, Indonesia became a full member. Additionally, Belarus, Bolivia, Cuba, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Nigeria, Thailand, Uganda, and Uzbekistan are currently associate members of the group.

summary: All seven experts converge on a low probability that a new country will be invited to join BRICS as a full member at the 17th BRICS Summit in July 2025. The core reasoning across perspectives centers on recent rapid expansion (notably from 2023–2025) which has induced institutional fatigue, capacity strains, and internal disagreement among members. Brazilian leadership, especially as summit host, is repeatedly cited as advocating a pause and consolidation, rather than further enlargement. The requirement for unanimity creates high barriers, with new and existing members expressing concerns about group cohesion, risk of rule-making paralysis, and political disagreements (underscored by failed joint declarations). The recent introduction of 'partner country' status is interpreted by all as a procedural move to manage expansion pressure without conferring full membership, further reducing short-term likelihood of upgrades. While demand from interested countries remains high and a small chance persists for a late political bargain—due to strategic imperatives or a major geopolitical shock—the consensus is that the most probable outcome is no new invitations for full membership at this summit. Most expert probability estimates cluster around 7–17%, with the modal forecast near 10%, reflecting a scenario that is not impossible but strongly disfavored by current signals and base rates.
